section.title: Defining relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: We use relative defining clauses to give information about things, people, possessions, places and times using a relative pronoun (who, which, that, etc.).
section.text1a: A scanner is a machine which can copy pictures.
section.text2a: A calculator is a little machine that does arithmetic.
section.text3a: A technophobe is someone who doesn't like machines.
section.text4a: A newsreader is a person that reads the news.

section.title: Relative defining clauses
section.text1: An orphan is a child. His/her parents have died.
section.text1a: An orphan is a child whose parents have died.
section.text2: An architect is a person. His/her job is to design buildings.
section.text2a: An architect is a person whose job is to design buildings.
section.sectiontitle2: We use where for places and when for times.
section.text3a: This is the house where I grew up.
section.text4a: The evening's a time when we can all relax.

section.title: Relative defining clauses
section.sectiontitle: We must use who, which, that when these are the subject of the relative clause.
section.text1: A journalist is a person. He writes for a newspaper or magazine. He is the subject.
section.text1a: A journalist is a person who writes for a newspaper or magazine.
section.text2: A modem is a machine. It connects a computer to the Internet.
section.text2a: A modem is a machine which connects a computer to the Internet.
section.sectiontitle2: We can leave out which, who and that if they are the object of the sentence.
section.text3: A colleague is someone. You work with them.
section.text3a: A colleague is someone you work with.
section.text4: Gloves are things. You wear them in cold weather.
section.text4a: Gloves are things you wear in cold weather.
